vision: AI-powered, multi-provider mail tagging and classification engine for Thunderbird

target_audience.primary: Privacy-conscious email power users who want automated intelligent email organization without manual filtering rules
secondary: IT professionals managing high email volumes
Small business owners needing automatic email categorization
Privacy-focused users preferring local AI (Ollama) over cloud services
Developers and technical users comfortable with LLM configuration

phases.name: Foundation & MVP Polish
phases.description: Complete the MVP with essential missing features, improve stability, and address critical user experience gaps. Focus on making the extension production-ready.

milestones.title: Manual Analysis Complete
milestones.description: Users can manually trigger AI analysis on selected emails with visual feedback

milestones.title: Classification Transparency
milestones.description: Users can see confidence scores and preview tag suggestions before applying

milestones.title: Production Stability
milestones.description: Extension is stable with clear error feedback and undo capability

phases.name: User Experience Enhancement
phases.description: Improve daily workflow with advanced features, bulk operations, and better configuration options. Make power users more productive.

milestones.title: Bulk Operations Ready
milestones.description: Users can re-analyze multiple emails and manage tags in bulk

milestones.title: Configuration Flexibility
milestones.description: Users can configure AI models, export settings, and customize behavior

phases.name: Intelligence & Analytics
phases.description: Add advanced AI features, learning capabilities, and analytics to provide deeper insights and continuous improvement.

milestones.title: Learning System Active
milestones.description: Extension learns from user corrections and provides smart suggestions

milestones.title: Analytics Dashboard Live
milestones.description: Users can view classification statistics, costs, and performance metrics

phases.name: Scale & Ecosystem
phases.description: Expand the extension's reach with internationalization, platform updates, and community features. Position for broader adoption.

milestones.title: Global Ready
milestones.description: Extension supports multiple languages and is prepared for international users

milestones.title: Future Proof
milestones.description: Extension migrated to Manifest V3 and has extensible provider architecture

milestones.title: Community Ecosystem
milestones.description: Users can share and discover tag configurations from the community

features.title: Manual Analysis Trigger from Message Context
features.description: Add a right-click context menu option and keyboard shortcut to manually trigger AI analysis on selected email(s). Users can analyze specific messages on-demand without waiting for automatic processing.
features.rationale: Users need control over when analysis happens. Addresses the gap where users can't analyze emails that arrived before extension installation or re-analyze with updated prompts. Competitors like manual Thunderbird filters require tedious rule creation (pain-4-1) - this provides an intelligent alternative.
acceptance_criteria: Right-click context menu shows 'Analyze with AI' option on selected messages
Keyboard shortcut (configurable) triggers analysis on selected messages
Multiple message selection is supported for batch manual analysis
Progress indicator shows analysis status
Results are applied immediately after analysis completes
user_stories: As an email power user, I want to manually trigger AI analysis on specific emails so that I can organize messages that arrived before I configured my tags
As a privacy-conscious user, I want to analyze only selected emails so that I control exactly which messages are processed by AI

features.title: Confidence Score Display and Threshold Configuration
features.description: Display confidence scores for AI classifications and allow users to configure minimum confidence thresholds. Tags are only applied when confidence exceeds the threshold.
features.rationale: Addresses market gap-5: lack of transparency in AI decisions. Gmail and SaneBox don't explain why emails are categorized (pain-3-3). Users need to understand AI certainty and control when tags are applied to avoid incorrect classifications.
acceptance_criteria: Confidence score (0-100%) is displayed alongside each tag suggestion
Global confidence threshold setting in options (default: 70%)
Per-tag confidence threshold override option
Low-confidence classifications are flagged for manual review
Confidence scores are stored with analysis history
user_stories: As a cautious user, I want to see confidence scores so that I can understand how certain the AI is about its classifications
As a power user, I want to set minimum confidence thresholds so that only high-confidence tags are applied automatically

features.title: Enhanced Error Feedback and Notifications
features.description: Provide clear, actionable error messages in the UI when API calls fail, models are unavailable, or configuration issues occur. Include notification system for analysis results and errors.
features.rationale: Current limited error feedback leaves users confused when things go wrong. Clear error messages reduce support requests and help users self-diagnose issues with their API keys, rate limits, or network connectivity.
acceptance_criteria: API errors show specific, actionable error messages (not just 'Error')
Rate limit errors suggest waiting time or switching providers
Invalid API key errors guide users to configuration
Network errors distinguish between connectivity and service issues
Optional desktop notifications for analysis completion/failure
Error history log accessible in options page
user_stories: As a new user, I want clear error messages so that I can fix configuration problems without searching documentation
As a power user, I want to be notified when batch analysis completes so that I don't have to manually check

features.title: Tag Suggestion Preview Before Application
features.description: Show proposed tags to users before applying them, with option to approve, reject, or modify. Supports both individual email preview and batch preview mode.
features.rationale: Users want control over what tags are applied. Preview mode builds trust in the AI system and prevents unwanted tagging. This is especially important for new users learning how their prompts work.
acceptance_criteria: Preview mode toggle in settings (preview all / auto-apply above threshold)
Preview UI shows email subject, proposed tags, and confidence scores
Users can approve, reject, or modify suggested tags
Batch preview shows list of emails with proposed tags
Quick approve/reject all buttons for batch operations
User modifications inform learning system (if enabled)
user_stories: As a new user, I want to preview tag suggestions so that I can verify my prompts are working correctly before auto-applying
As a careful user, I want to approve tags before they're applied so that I maintain control over my email organization

features.title: Undo Mechanism and Analysis History
features.description: Allow users to undo recent tag applications and view a history/audit log of all AI classifications. History includes timestamp, email subject, applied tags, confidence scores, and provider used.
features.rationale: Addresses known gap for undo mechanism and audit log. Users need to correct AI mistakes easily and review past classifications. This builds trust and enables users to refine their prompts based on historical performance.
acceptance_criteria: Undo button in notification after tags are applied
Undo option in message context menu for recently tagged messages
Analysis history page showing last 1000 classifications
History entries include: timestamp, email subject, tags, confidence, provider
Filter history by date range, tag, or confidence level
Export history as CSV for analysis
History stored locally with configurable retention period
user_stories: As a user, I want to undo incorrect tag applications so that I can easily correct AI mistakes
As a power user, I want to review analysis history so that I can evaluate how well my prompts are working

features.title: Bulk Re-Analysis Capability
features.description: Allow users to re-analyze multiple emails with updated tag prompts or different AI providers. Supports filtering by folder, date range, or existing tags.
features.rationale: When users refine their prompts, they need to re-process existing emails. Currently there's no way to bulk re-analyze, forcing manual one-by-one processing. This is essential for iterating on classification quality.
acceptance_criteria: Re-analyze button for selected emails in folder view
Filter options: by folder, date range, existing tags, or no tags
Option to clear existing AI-applied tags before re-analysis
Progress tracking for bulk re-analysis operations
Pause/cancel capability for long-running operations
Summary report showing changes after re-analysis
user_stories: As a user who refined my prompts, I want to re-analyze old emails so that they get updated tags based on my improved classification criteria
As a power user, I want to re-analyze emails with a different AI provider so that I can compare classification quality

features.title: Enhanced Tag Management Interface
features.description: Improved UI for creating, editing, and organizing tags. Support for tag groups, drag-and-drop reordering, prompt templates, and tag statistics.
features.rationale: Unlimited custom tags with natural language prompts is a key differentiator (gap-2, pain-1-3). The tag management UI should make this power accessible and easy to use. Good UX here drives adoption.
acceptance_criteria: Tag groups for organizing related tags
Drag-and-drop reordering of tags
Prompt templates library with common classification patterns
Copy/duplicate existing tags as starting point
Tag usage statistics (email count, last used, avg confidence)
Test prompt feature to validate against sample emails
Search/filter tags by name or prompt content
user_stories: As a user with many tags, I want to organize them into groups so that I can manage my classification system efficiently
As a new user, I want prompt templates so that I can quickly set up effective classification criteria

features.title: Configurable AI Models for Cloud Providers
features.description: Allow users to select specific AI models within each provider (e.g., GPT-4 vs GPT-3.5, Claude 3 Opus vs Sonnet). Show model capabilities and pricing estimates.
features.rationale: Currently models are hardcoded. Users want to choose models based on cost, speed, or quality tradeoffs. This enables cost-conscious users to use cheaper models while power users can opt for premium ones. Addresses market gap-4 on multi-provider flexibility.
acceptance_criteria: Model dropdown selector for each cloud provider
API call to fetch available models (where supported)
Manual model input for providers without model list API
Model descriptions showing capabilities and relative cost
Different models can be configured for different tag classifications
Settings persist and sync across sessions
user_stories: As a cost-conscious user, I want to use GPT-3.5 instead of GPT-4 so that I can save money on API costs
As a power user, I want to use Claude 3 Opus for complex classifications so that I get higher accuracy

features.title: Configuration Export/Import
features.description: Export all extension settings (tags, prompts, provider configs, preferences) to a JSON file. Import settings to restore configuration or share with others.
features.rationale: Users need to backup their carefully crafted tag configurations, migrate between computers, or share setups with team members. This is a common feature request and low-effort high-value addition.
acceptance_criteria: Export button generates downloadable JSON file
Export includes: tags, prompts, provider settings, preferences
API keys are optionally excluded from export for security
Import validates file structure before applying
Merge or replace options when importing
Version compatibility check in import
Confirmation dialog before overwriting existing settings
user_stories: As a user setting up a new computer, I want to import my configuration so that I don't have to recreate all my tags and prompts
As a team lead, I want to export my tag configuration so that I can share it with team members for consistency

features.title: Performance Optimization for Large Emails
features.description: Implement intelligent email truncation and token budgeting. Configure maximum content length, skip attachments option, and smart excerpt extraction for large emails.
features.rationale: Large emails with attachments consume many tokens, increasing costs and response time. Smart truncation extracts the most relevant content while staying within token budgets. Essential for cost control.
acceptance_criteria: Configurable maximum token/character limit per email
Toggle to skip attachment content analysis
Smart truncation preserving email headers and key content
Estimated token count shown before analysis
Warning when email exceeds token budget
Priority order: sender, subject, first N paragraphs, last paragraph
user_stories: As a cost-conscious user, I want to limit email content length so that I don't spend too many tokens on long emails
As a user receiving large attachments, I want to skip attachment analysis so that classification focuses on the message itself

features.title: Learning from User Corrections
features.description: Track when users modify or reject AI-suggested tags. Use this feedback to improve prompt suggestions and highlight patterns where classifications frequently need correction.
features.rationale: Competitors like Gmail Smart Categories learn from corrections (strength). Our system should too. This addresses pain-4-4 where Thunderbird filters don't learn. Feedback loop improves classification quality over time.
acceptance_criteria: Track all user modifications to AI-applied tags
Analyze correction patterns to identify weak prompts
Suggest prompt improvements based on correction patterns
Dashboard showing per-tag correction rates
Option to include correction context in future prompts
Privacy-respecting: all learning data stays local
user_stories: As a user, I want the system to learn from my corrections so that classification accuracy improves over time
As a power user, I want to see which tags have high correction rates so that I can improve those prompts

features.title: Classification Reasoning Display
features.description: Show the AI's reasoning for why specific tags were suggested. Optionally include reasoning request in prompts to get explanations from the LLM.
features.rationale: Directly addresses gap-5 and pain-3-3: lack of transparency in AI decisions. Understanding 'why' helps users refine prompts and builds trust in the system. Differentiates from opaque competitors.
acceptance_criteria: Optional 'explain reasoning' toggle in settings
Reasoning displayed alongside tag suggestions in preview
Reasoning stored in analysis history
Concise explanation format (1-2 sentences)
Reasoning helps identify prompt weaknesses
Minimal impact on API costs (reasoning adds few tokens)
user_stories: As a curious user, I want to see why emails are classified a certain way so that I can understand the AI's decision-making
As a power user refining prompts, I want classification reasoning so that I can identify what triggers incorrect classifications

features.title: Analytics Dashboard
features.description: Visual dashboard showing classification statistics, API usage, costs, response times, and trends over time. Helps users understand and optimize their email AI usage.
features.rationale: Addresses known gap for performance monitoring. Users want to see how well the extension is working and how much it's costing them. Analytics build confidence and enable optimization.
acceptance_criteria: Dashboard page in options with visual charts
Metrics: emails analyzed, tags applied, confidence distribution
API usage: calls per provider, tokens consumed, estimated costs
Performance: average response time, success/failure rates
Time-based views: daily, weekly, monthly trends
Per-tag statistics: usage frequency, avg confidence
Export analytics data as CSV
user_stories: As a cost-conscious user, I want to see my API usage and costs so that I can budget my email AI spending
As a power user, I want to see classification trends so that I can understand how well my system is working

features.title: Email Summary Generation
features.description: Option to generate brief AI summaries of emails alongside classification. Useful for quickly understanding email content without reading the full message.
features.rationale: Value-add feature leveraging the same AI infrastructure. When AI is analyzing email content, it can easily generate a summary. This adds utility beyond just tagging and differentiates from competitors.
acceptance_criteria: Toggle to enable email summarization
Summary length option: one-line / short paragraph
Summary displayed in custom header or note
Summaries stored with analysis results
Option to summarize only emails over certain length
Summary respects email privacy (no external storage)
user_stories: As a busy professional, I want email summaries so that I can quickly understand message content without reading everything
As a user with many newsletters, I want summaries so that I can decide which ones are worth reading in full

features.title: Internationalization (i18n) Support
features.description: Translate the extension UI to multiple languages. Support for RTL languages, locale-aware date/time formatting, and community-contributed translations.
features.rationale: Known gap: no localization support. Thunderbird has global users. i18n is essential for broader adoption and AMO (addons.mozilla.org) distribution. Low effort per locale once infrastructure is in place.
acceptance_criteria: WebExtension i18n API integration
All UI strings externalized to messages.json
Initial languages: English, German, Spanish, French
Language auto-detection from Thunderbird settings
Manual language override option
RTL support for Arabic, Hebrew
Contribution guide for community translators
user_stories: As a German speaker, I want the extension UI in German so that I can use it comfortably in my native language
As a translator, I want clear contribution guidelines so that I can help translate the extension to my language

features.title: Manifest V3 Migration
features.description: Migrate from Manifest V2 to V3 to ensure future Thunderbird compatibility. Update background scripts to service workers, revise permissions, and adapt to new CSP requirements.
features.rationale: Critical technical debt: Thunderbird will require Manifest V3 in future versions. Extension will stop working without this migration. High complexity but essential for longevity.
acceptance_criteria: Manifest updated to version 3
Background script converted to service worker
Permissions updated to declarativeNetRequest where needed
CSP adjustments for stricter V3 requirements
All existing functionality preserved
Tested on Thunderbird beta with V3 support
Fallback for older Thunderbird versions during transition
user_stories: As a Thunderbird user, I want the extension to work with future Thunderbird versions so that I don't lose my email AI assistant
As a developer, I want modern Manifest V3 architecture so that the extension follows current best practices

features.title: Extensible Provider Architecture
features.description: Refactor provider system to support dynamic registration and community-contributed providers. Plugin-like architecture for adding new AI providers without code changes.
features.rationale: Currently new providers require code changes. An extensible architecture enables community contributions and faster adoption of new AI services. Reduces maintenance burden.
acceptance_criteria: Provider interface/contract clearly defined
Providers registered via configuration, not code
Custom provider endpoint configuration option
Provider validation on registration
Documentation for adding custom providers
Example provider template for community
Graceful handling of provider errors/unavailability
user_stories: As a developer, I want to add custom AI providers so that I can use my company's internal LLM
As a user, I want provider flexibility so that I can quickly adopt new AI services as they become available

features.title: Community Tag Library
features.description: Platform for sharing and discovering tag configurations. Users can publish their tag setups and import configurations shared by others. Curated categories for common use cases.
features.rationale: Leverages network effects for growth. New users can quickly set up effective classifications by importing community templates. Power users gain recognition for contributions.
acceptance_criteria: In-app browser for community tag configurations
One-click import of community tags
Categories: work email, newsletters, personal, dev/github
Rating/voting system for quality control
Privacy: no email content shared, only tag definitions
Moderation to prevent spam/malicious content
Attribution and credit for contributors
user_stories: As a new user, I want to browse community tags so that I can quickly set up effective email organization
As a power user, I want to share my tag configurations so that others can benefit from my setup
